questions.text: A homeless malnourished chronic alcoholic with right lobar pneumonia undergoes a sputum examination which reveals partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods. Which of the the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods suggest Nocardia. 

Infections caused by Nocardia can occur in immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals.

Nocardia cause three types of skin infections in immunocompetent individuals:

• Mycetoma, a chronic, localized, painless, subcutaneous infection

• Lymphocutaneous infections

• Skin abscesses or cellulitis

In immunocompromised individuals, Nocardia can cause invasive pulmonary infections and disseminated infections.

Patients usually appear systemically ill, with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and a productive cough that may be bloody. Pulmonary infection can lead to complications such as pleural effusions, empyema, mediastinitis, and soft tissue infection.

An acute inflammatory response follows infection, resulting in necrosis and abscess formation. Granulomas are not usually formed.

Mycobacteria are acid fast bacilli but without branching rods.

questions.text: 32 year old AIDS positive female presented with headaches and nuchal stiffness. The microscopic examination of India-ink stained CSF is shown in the image given below. The causative organism is:
questions.solution:
The microscopic examination of India-ink stained CSF is shows unicellular budding yeast with a prominent capsule- cryptococcus. Cryptococcus is known to cause meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with hemoptysis and anemia. His renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerulonephritis with a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome/ anti-glomerular basement membrane disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

It is mediated by autoantibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane and the pulmonary alveolus.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

Antibodies that react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
  • Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
  • Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
  • Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
  • Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor)

Antibodies can coat (opsonize) cells, with or without complement proteins, and target these cells for phagocytosis
  • Transfusion reactions
  • Erythroblastosis fetalis
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura

Antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Vasculitis due to ANCA
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Vascular rejection in organ grafts

TSH: Thyroid stimulating hormone

ANCA: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody

 

 

Image: Type II hypersensitivity reaction

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Prototypical Disorders

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma,Atopic dermatitis

Antibody-mediated (type II)hypersensitivity

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia; Goodpasture syndrome

Immune complex-mediated (type III) hypersensitivity

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity

Activated T lymphocytes →

(1) the release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation;

(2) T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Contact dermatitis; multiple sclerosis; type 1 diabetes; tuberculosis

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who was admitted to the hospital for leukemia with fever develops diarrhea after the administration of ampicillin antibiotic. Which of the following type of motility is exhibited by the most common causative agent responsible for diarrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Clostridium difficile induced diarrhoea. Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of healthcare-associated diarrhoea. It shows Stately motility.

  • All clostridia are motile, with peritrichate flagella, except C. perfringens and Clostridium tetani type VI which are non-motile.
  • Motility is slow and has been described as 'stately'.
  • Clostridium difficile induced diarrhoea usually occurs following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin or fluoroquinolones to which the organism is resistant.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

questions.text: A girl  goes diving in a village pond with her friend and then develops nasal discharge, meningitis and dies in 5 days. Organism responsible is:
questions.solution:
The organism is Naegleria fowleri which is the only species which infects man.

Its a pathogenic free living amoebae which causes the disease primary amoebic meningiencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, infection comes from water containing free living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The  amoeba invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges  and  brain  to initiate an acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period ,the patient experiences anosmia, disease advances rapidly ,causing fever ,headache,vomiting ,stiff neck ,ataxia,seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week.(average 5 days).

Treatment -

Drug of choice is amphotericin -B intravenously.It can also be instilled directly into the brain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male from a suburban area presented with fever and rash, involving the palms and soles. He gives a history of bite by an organism that looks like the one seen in the image below. His vitals are stable and there is no eschar formation at the site of the bite. Which of the following can be a likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hard tick and a history of characteristic rash present on palms and soles after a tick bite and no eschar is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever due to  Rickettsia rickettsii infection.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever presents with fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia as the most common symptoms during the first 3 days. Rash is evident in only 14% of patients on the first day of illness, which is present on palms and soles.

The most common serologic test for confirmation of the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. It is administered orally at 100 mg twice daily.

Rash on palms and soles is typically described in the following 3 diseases:

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Hand Foot and Mouth Disease.

 The image shows a hard tick that can transmit-

  • Tick typhus (Rickettsia conorii)
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Kyasanur forest disease
  • Tularemia
  • Human babesiosis(Babesia microti)
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia rickettsii).

Identification of the tick alone helps rule out the other options as Rickettsia prowazekii is louse-borne, Rickettsia typhi is flea-borne and Rickettsia tsutsugamushi is mite-borne. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are the hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • General morphology of ticks includes an oval shaped body, four pairs of legs and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in front. Absent.
Head Situated at anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body, ventrally. Not visible from above.
Spiracles Situated behind coxa IV. Situated between III and IV coxa.
Eggs Several hundred/thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Can’t stand starvation; feed night and day. Can stand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Q fever(reservoir), relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion and toxaphone. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented to the OPD with intractable diarrhea. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. What is the peculiar feature of this parasite which differentiates it from other coccidian parasites?

choices.text: It has Faeco-oral route of transmission
Parasites multiply asexually within the intestinal cells
Oocysts passed in the feaces are immediately infectious

questions.solution:
Oocysts passed in the feaces are immediately infectious in the case of cryptosporidium parvum, as they are sporulated oocysts.

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts suggest modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, containing four sporozoites which are uniformly acid-fast on staining.

In other coccidian parasites namely, cyclospora and isospora, unsporulated oocysts are passed in the stool. Unsporulated oocysts take days or weeks to become infectious, and because of this, direct person-to-person transmission through fecal exposure is unlikely to occur.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection Uniformly acid-fast Variably acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Kinyoun stain positive images of Isospora:

questions.text: Valley fever or desert rheumatism refers to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
• Coccidioidomycosis commonly known as Valley fever or desert rheumatism is a mammalian fungal disease caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii.
  • C. posadasii and C. immitis are morphologically identical, but genetically and epidemiologically distinct.
  • Infections usually occur due to inhalation of the arthroconidial spores after soil disruption.

Signs & Symptoms:

  • The primary infection is most often respiratory, with symptoms resembling bronchitis or pneumonia that resolve over a matter of a few weeks.
  • The classic triad of coccidioidomycosis known as "desert rheumatism" includes the combination of fever, joint pains, and erythema nodosum.
  • Chronic fibro cavitary disease is manifested by cough, sputum, fevers, night sweats and weight loss.
  • Osteomyelitis, including involvement of the spine, and meningitis which may occur months to years after initial infection.

Coccidioidomycosis may be divided into the following types:

  1. Acute coccidioidomycosis, sometimes described in literature as primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis
  2. Chronic coccidioidomycosis
  3. Disseminated coccidioidomycosis, which includes primary cutaneous coccidioidomycosis

Treatment:

  • Fluconazole and intravenous amphotericin B are used in progressive or disseminated disease, or in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Itraconazole or ketoconazole may be used for milder disease.
  • Fluconazole is the preferred medication for coccidioidal meningitis, due to its penetration into CSF.
  • Intrathecal or intraventricular amphotericin B therapy is used if infection persists after fluconazole treatment.
  • The antifungal medications posaconazole and voriconazole have also been used to treat coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture
questions.solution:
• Legionella pneumophilia has fastidious growth requirements and hence grows on complex media such as BYCE - Buffered Charcoal, Yeast extract agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.
  • It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

Composition of BCYE Agar and functions of each ingredient

  1. Agar
  2. ACES buffer: ACES buffer is added to maintain the proper pH for optimal growth.
  3. Yeast extract: Yeast extract supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  4. Charcoal: Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species, and may also collect carbon dioxide and modify surface tension
  5. L-Cysteine: L-Cysteine is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  6. Ferric Pyrophosphate: used as an Iron supplement; iron source
  7. Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt: Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth

The image below shows growth of legionella on BYCE medium

Note: BYCE has also been used for the recovery of Acanthamoeba keratitis

questions.text: A long term Intravenous port has been revised after it becomes blocked and the catheter is found to contain bacterial contaminants. Which of the following attributes is most likely to be a factor in this pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Catheters, shunts and prosthetic devices which are left in the body long-term, are almost always coated with Teflon which is extremely slippery.

Organisms which are capable of adherence to Teflon (or the enamel of teeth), do so by creation of a biofilm, which allows them to change the surface tension of the liquid around them and thereby “glue” themselves to the material.

Other options:

Option b: Ergosterol is the major sterol in the cell wall of fungi, and is important in membrane integrity, but not adherence.

Option c: Peptidoglycan is the cell wall material of bacteria, and is responsible for the shape of bacteria, but not their adherence.

Option d: IgA proteases can assist in the adherence of bacteria to mucosal surfaces, but would not be important in adherence to an intravenous catheter.

questions.text: Which of the following infections gives positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins?
questions.solution:
• Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction in which the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K.
  • Basis of the test is sharing of an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 & OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K.
  • OX K is agglutinated only in Scrub typhus.

Good to know:

  • Similar antigens present on dissimilar organisms are heterophile antigens.
  • Antibodies reacting with such antigens are called heterophile antibodies.
  • Serologic tests employing these heterophile antigens are called Heterophile agglutination tests.

Inference of Agglutination pattern in Weil-Felix Reaction

Disease             OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Epidemic typhus +++ + -
Endemic typhus +++ +/- -
RMSF ++ ++ -
Scrub typhus - - +++
Rickettsial pox - - -
Trench fever - - -
Q fever - - -

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae toxin acts by disrupting  which of these structure?
questions.solution:
Zona occludens is disrupted by Vibrio Cholerae.

Vibrio chollerae also produces additional toxins that may contribute to disease, including the zonula occludens toxin (ZOT) that alters intestinal permeability by acting on intestinal epithelial cells tight junctions and the accessory cholera endotoxin.

questions.text: Sabin Feldman dye test is done for
questions.solution:
• Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.
  • The test is false positive in case of
    • Sarcocystis
    • Trichomonas vaginalis
    • Trypanosoma Lewisii infections
  • IIF, IHA and CFT are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.
  • Dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection.
  • ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts through the receptor marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ticlopidine acts through the ADP receptor of the platelet and prevents its recruitment and activation.

Other drugs that act through the ADP receptor are:

  • Clopidogrel
  • Prasugrel
  • Cangrelor
  • Ticagrelor

Drugs that act through GPIIb/IIIa are:

  • Abciximab
  • Tirofiban
  • Eptifibatide

questions.text: Which of the following skeletal muscle relaxants exhibit the following response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine exhibits the above-given response to the 'train of four protocol' used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.

Train of four protocol:

  • This is one of the methods used in the clinical assessment of neuromuscular blockade.
  • It is most commonly done by stimulating the ulnar nerve with a stimulus and watching the contractile responses in the adductor pollicis muscle of the hand.
  • Four successive stimuli of 2Hz strength is given at fixed time intervals and the response achieved is plotted as a graph.

When an agent belonging to the curare group which are the nondepolarizing/competitive blockers is used, it shows fade phenomenon. This is because, during the initial stimulus, the amount of acetylcholine released is large enough to compete with the drug at the motor endplate and causes the maximal contraction of the muscle. But, during the successive stimuli, the amount of acetylcholine released is not sufficient to compete with the drug and results in diminished contractions sequentially. This is called as the Fade phenomenon.

When succinylcholine, the only depolarising agent in clinical use is used the train of four protocol does not show fade phenomenon. This happens so because there is no competition that exists between Sch and Ach. Also, succinylcholine acts like acetylcholine at its receptors but they are not easily metabolized by acetylcholinesterases resulting in persistent depolarisation. This is phase 1 blockade.

But when the dose of succinylcholine is increased maximally, it also exhibits a fade phenomenon. This is phase 2 blockade.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female, diagnosed with bipolar disorder and under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination. Urine specific gravity is 1 and the urine osmolality is 180 mOsm/kg. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI), for which the most appropriate treatment is amiloride.

Principle:

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into renal distal tubule ENaCs and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

questions.text: During your pharmacology viva, The examiner gives a scenario where 2 persons "A" and "B" diagnosed with type 1  and type 2 diabetes respectively need to be treated with a single glucose-lowering agent. Which of the following agents would you pick for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Pramlintide can be used in both Type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus. It is a synthetic analogue of amylin.

Islet amyloid peptide (amylin) is produced from pancreatic beta-cell. It acts in specific regions of hindbrain resulting in a reduction in glucagon release, delayed gastric emptying, and satiety. It is approved for the treatment of types 1 and 2 diabetes as an adjunct in patients who take insulin with meals. The most common adverse effects are nausea and hypoglycemia.

Exenatide, Liraglutide, and Tolbutamide are not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus. Because the beta cells are already destroyed in Type 1 DM and there is no role of any insulin secretagogues or any drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep. He is feeling comfortable only after doing so. He is also experiencing burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs. What is the ideal drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of the student complaining of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep and feeling comfortable only after doing so, along with having burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs indicative of a diagnosis of restless leg syndromeand the ideal drug of choice for this condition is gabapentin.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is anirresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep or anuncomfortable sensation of creeping-crawling feeling.It is worse at night and moving legs or walking reduces discomfort.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approveddrugs for thetreatmentof restless leg syndrome:

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Other options:

  • Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • Rilmenidine is an imidazoline receptor agonist that is used for the management of hypertension.
  • Rimonabant is an inverse agonist of the CB1 (cannabinoid receptor) that was used as an anti-obesity medication.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on an anticancer drug. After a few days, the patient started passing blood in the urine for which mesna was used as a treatment. This side effect is due to the ______ component of this anticancer drug.
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis as a side effect due to the toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide called acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercaptoethanesulfonate(mesna).

Cyclophoshamide is metabolised by hepatic cytochrome enzyme to form 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide. The tautomer of 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide called aldophosphamide cleaves non enzymatically in the tumor cell to form phosphoramide mustard and acrolein. Phosphoramide mustard is responsible for antitumor effects, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female had 6 attacks of migraine in the last month and was treated for the same. She is not able to tolerate the pain during attacks and came to the hospital asking for medication which can prevent these attacks in the future. The drug which can be used in this patient is ________.
questions.solution:
The drug which can be used in this patient to prevent migraine attack is topiramate.

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in prevention of chronic migraine

Drugs that have not shown benefit in the prophylaxis of migraine: Verapamil, Diltiazem (a calcium channel blocker), nimodipine, clonidine, fluoxetine (an SSRI).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the OPD. His parents describe that the boy had an episode of abnormal jerking movements that started in his left hand and gradually involved the entire arm. Following this, the patient experienced weakness and difficulty in moving the left arm for about an hour. Two similar episodes have also occurred in the past. His father is a known case of epilepsy. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the first-line drug used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describesJacksonian march followed by Todds palsy. These arecharacteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures iscarbamazepine which is a sodium-channel blocker.

First-line agents in the treatment of focal seizures:

  • Lamotrigine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used inGTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result inwater retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched pair based on side effects?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis is not the side effect of Gabapentin.

Gabapentin is orally absorbed but not metabolized in humans and excreted in urine and are not bound to plasma proteins.

This lipophilic GABA derivative crosses to the brain and enhances GABA release. Gabapentin and its newer congener pregabalin exert a specific analgesic effect in neuropathic pain.

Uses:

  • First line drug for neuralgic pain due to diabetic neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia.
  • Added to a first line drug, gabapentin reduces seizure frequency in refractory partial seizures with or without generalization. It is mostly employed as add-on drug.
  • Prophylactic effect in migraine
  • Alternative drug for phobic states.

Side effects include:

  • Mild sedation
  • Tiredness
  • Dizziness
  • Unsteadiness

Other options:

  • Lamotrigine- Steven Johnson syndrome
  • Topiramate- Renal calculi

Vigabatrin-  Concentric visual field contraction due to retinal atrophy

questions.text: Naltrexone is used for which of the following function in opioid addiction?
questions.solution:
• Naltrexone is an orally active opioid antagonist that is used for prevention of relapse in opioid deaddiction after detoxification.
  • Overdose of opioid is treated with short acting parenteral agent, naloxone (Option D).
  • Opioid antagonists are not used in opioid withdrawal as it can precipitate the condition (Options B and C).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be given along with levodopa
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa (not combined with carbidopa) by enhancing its peripheral decarboxylation so that less of it remains available to cross to the brain.

Drug Interactions of Levodopa

  • Pyridoxine: Abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa 
  • Phenothiazines, butyrophenones, metoclopramide reverse the therapeutic effect of levodopa by blocking DA receptors
  • Nonselective MAO inhibitors along with levodopa may cause hypertensive crisis
  • Antihypertensive drugs accentuate the postural hypotension caused by levodopa
  • Antiparkinsonian anticholinergic drugs have additive therapeutic action with low doses of levodopa, but retard its absorption—more time is available for peripheral degradation—efficacy of levodopa may be reduced.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding first order kinetics are true except:

choices.text: Rate of elimination is proportional to plasma conc
Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

questions.solution:
In first order kinetics, constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time.

Difference Between First and Zero Order Kinetics

 

 First Order Kinetics  Zero Order Kinetics
The rate of elimination is directly proportional to the drug conc. The rate of elimination remains constant irrespective of drug conc.
Clearance remains constant. Clearance decreases with increase in conc.
Constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in unittime. Constant amount of the drug is eliminated in unit time.
t½ remains constant t½ increases with dose

Drugs following zero order kinetics/Capacity limited elimination/Michaelis-Menten elimination:

  • Ethanol
  • Methanol

Kinetics changes from first order to zero order at higher doses for:

  • Warfarin
  • Theophylline
  • Tolbutamide
  • Phenytoin

choices.text: Phase I  Access efficacy and dosage
Phase II  In most cases drugs are first time introduced in patients
Phase III  Multisite trial involving thousands of patients

questions.solution:

questions.text: Metal fume fever is common in poisoning with____
questions.solution:
Metal fume fever is common in poisoning with zinc.

Metal fume fever (Also called Smelter shakes/Brass chills/Monday morning fever) was described as early as 1669 in brass foundry workers as ‘brass foundry man’s ague’.

  • Symptoms of metal fume fever occur up to 24 hours after exposure to zinc oxide fumes.
  • It presents as an influenza-like illness with a headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains.
  • Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term ‘Monday morning fever’.
  • The illness usually has a good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops.
  • It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxide fumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur.
  • The pathogenesis is not known but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.
  • Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome.

Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead antimony, silver, and aluminum, etc.

questions.text: The method of identification used in forensic lab as shown in the image below is based on
questions.solution:
• Poroscopy is a method of personal identification through the comparison of the impressions of sweat pores (present on friction ridges of palmar and plantar surfaces).
  • The method was discovered and developed by Edmond Locard in 1912.
  • It includes the study of the configuration, size, and relative position of the pores in human skin.

questions.text: Post mortem lividity as shown in the photograph below is due to poisoning by _____
questions.solution:
The above photograph shows postmortem lividity with bright cherry red discolouration seen in Carbon monoxide poisoning.

  • Post mortem lividity or hypostasis or Livor mortis is the settling of blood under the influence of gravity which develops in the early post mortem interval.
  • Livor mortis starts in 20–30 minutes, but is usually not observable by the human eye until two hours after death. The size of the patches increases in the next three to six hours.
  • Lividity is said to become fixed between 8 and 12 hours after death, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.

Colour of post mortem lividity (hypostasis) in various conditions.

Condition Colour of hypostasis
Normal Bluish pink which later turns into bluish purple
Carbon monoxide poisoning Bright cherry red
Cyanide poisoning Pink
Phosphorus poisoning Dark brown
Nitrate poisoning Reddish brown
Chlorate poisoning Chocolate brown
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning Bluish Green
Aniline poisoning Deep blue
Opiate poisoning Black

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

questions.text: Ashley's rule is used for determination of _____________
questions.solution:
Ashley’s rule is used to know sex from the sternum bone. It is also known as 149 rule. According to ashley's rule, male sternum has total length of >149 mm and female sternum has total length of <149 mm.

Features Male sternum Female sternum
Body Bigger,longer and more than 2x length of manubrium Shorter and less than 2x length of manubrium
Ashley’s rule Total length>149mm Total length <149mm
Level of upper border At the level of lower part of body of 2nd thoracic vertebrae At the level of lower part of 3rd thoracic vertebrae
manubrium smaller bigger
Sternal index 46.2 54.3

 

 Sternal index = Length of manubrium x 100/length of body of sternum

questions.text: While inspecting a crime scene of a murder case, whiskey glasses were found on the table. The latent prints from the glass can be visualised by all except___________
questions.solution:
Pearson method is not used for visualisation of latent fingerprints. Pearson’s method is used for estimation of stature from a skeleton. All other options given can be used for visualisation of latent prints.

Latent prints are those that are left behind through interaction of hands, palms, and feet with the environment. Occasionally these prints are left cleanly so as to be clearly visible to the unaided eye. It is more often the case that the prints are only partially visible or not visible at all without the use of specialized fingerprint-processing methods and equipment.

Methods to enhance fingerprints:

  • Lighting - White light, photoluminescence, ultraviolet spectrum lighting
  • Physical - Dusting a surface with a fine powder of contrasting color
  • Chemical - Ninhydrin, Cyanoacrylate fuming, silver nitrate

Powders used:

  • White : Lead carbonate
  • Black  : Charcoal
  • Grey : Aluminium dust OR chalk powder + mercury

questions.text: A police officer while investigating a case of infantile homicide asks a forensic expert to estimate the age of the dead infant. The forensic expert estimates the age as 6 months by counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth. Which of the following methods has been used by the forensic expert for age estimation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Boyde’s method is being used by the forensic expert for estimating the age of the dead infant.

Boyde’s method:

  • This method is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from the neonatal line onwards. The neonatal line is formed soon after birth and can be seen in about 3 weeks or by electron microscopy 1–2 days after birth.
  • This method is applicable mainly to estimate the age of dead infants.

Other options:

Stack’s method: Determination of age is done from the weight of the erupting teeth of the fetus/ infant.

Miles' method: Age estimation is made on the basis of comparison the amount of wear on all three permanent molars with the baseline.

Gustafson’s Method: It is based on physiological changes in teeth. Gustafson’s criteria include,

  • Attrition: Wear and tear changes of the occlusal surface.
  • Periodontosis: Regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.
  • Secondary dentin: Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity.
  • Cementum apposition: Deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption: Involves both cementum and dentin.
  • Transparency of the root: This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled by mineral and they become less transparent.

questions.text: A dead body is brought in for post mortem immediately after the death. You notice that the temperature of the body remains raised for about the first two hours after death. This is explained by:
questions.solution:
Condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for about first two hours after death is termed as postmortem caloricity. 

Strychnine poisoning, septicaemia and sun stroke lead to increase in body temperature for first 2 hours following death.

The condition occurs:

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicaemia, cholera.

Other options:

  • Cooling of the body after death is termed as algor mortis
  • Suggillation is same as livor mortis and refers to postmortem staining

questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound of a shotgun as shown below. You would suspect that it was most likely shot at a distance range of ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun which can be seen from 1 to 5 meters of range.

Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 30cm-1m range.

Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 1m-5m range.

The rat-hole appearance of the entry wound:

 

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

  • Soft tissues - single circular wound about the diameter of the muzzle with muzzle imprint and no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.
  • Bone - same as with soft tissues, but wound may be ragged and split because of gas rebound.

<30 cm

  • Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling.
  • Burnt hairs (singeing).
  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

30cm - 1m

  • Circular rat-hole wound.
  • Soot soiling.
  • Powder tattooing.

1 - 5 meters

  • Central rat-hole wound.
  • No soot, tattooing +/-.
  • Satellite pellet holes around the periphery.

>5 meters

  • Diffuse pellet pattern
  • No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female was admitted for a strangulated femoral hernia. She came with complaints of abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and recession of intestines with an end to end anastomosis. The next day she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is appropriate for the line I (a) of the death certificate as it is the disease/condition directly leading to death.

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Peritonitis
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: Perforation of small intestine
  • I(c) - Condition which gave rise to the antecedent cause: Strangulated femoral hernia

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are just signs of death and provide no useful information as to the underlying disease process.

Refer the last line in the death certificate with an asterisk (*).

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: Magistrate's inquest is done in _________

choices.text: When the family wants to reconduct the inquest

questions.solution:
Magistrate's inquest is done in the case of death due to police firing.

BNSS 196 or section 176 Cr. P.C. deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances.A magistrates inquest is an inquest conducted by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, and magistrate of the first class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the State Government, such as Collector, Deputy Collector, or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates).

Special Magistrates inquests are held in cases of:

  • Lock-up deaths
  • Deaths while under police interrogation
  • Deaths in prison
  • Deaths in police custody
  • Deaths due to police firing
  • Exhumation
  • Alleged dowry death
  • In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Note: It is practised throughout India. However, it is not held routinely but held only on special indications mentioned above. In any case of unnatural death, the magistrate may hold an inquest instead of/ in addition to the police inquest.

Police Inquest: The inquest is held by a police officer (called Investigating Officer) not below the rank of Senior Head Constable. It is practised throughout India.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with halitosis and regurgitation, he was subjected to a barium swallow scan which is given below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The suspected condition is Zenker's diverticulum which originates through the Killian's dehiscence, which is present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fibres and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called as the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

This is the site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall and therefore is the potential site for the development of the diverticula (Zenker's diverticula).

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenkers Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
The lumbricals and interossei muscles are affected.

Lumbricals and interossei muscles through their attachments to the dorsal digital expansions, cause:

  • Flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Extension of the interphalangeal (IP) joints

In cases ofulnar nerve injury, these muscles may get atrophied leading to the extension of MCP joints and flexion of IP joints.

Note:The ulnar nerve innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for

  • First and second lumbricals
  • Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Opponens pollicis
  • Part of flexor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Following prolonged spine surgery in a prone position, a patient develops Meralgia paresthetica and complaints of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the involved nerve?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of thigharises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

questions.text: A baby was born with an oblique cleft on the face along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct was exposed to the surface. Failure of fusion of ______ processes explains this deformity.

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and Mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and Maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and Mandibular prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and Maxillary prominence

questions.solution:
The oblique facial cleft is due to failure of fusion of the maxillary prominence and corresponding lateral nasal prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows: 

  • Cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both the nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors. 
  • Median (midline) cleft lip is a rare defect occurring due to failure of the two medial nasal prominences to fuse in the midline. 
  • Oblique facial cleft is caused by the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct is exposed to the surface in these cases.

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as thesuperior mesenteric artery,as it liesanterior and superior to the left renal vein.The superior mesenteric artery originated from theabdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra,about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: The given image shows the muscles present in the palmer aspect of the left hand. Which among the following is the nerve supply of the muscle marked as "A"?

choices.text: Superficial branch of the ulnar nerve

questions.solution:
The muscle marked as "A" in the above image is Abductor digiti minimi. It is innervated by the deep branch of ulnar nerve.

Abductor digiti minimi arises from the pisiform bone,the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris and the pisohamate ligament.

It is an abductor of the little finger. It plays an important role when the hand is grasping large objects with outspread fingers.

questions.text: A cadaveric specimen of the circle of Willis is given below. Which of the following marked structures represents the superior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric image is of the vascular structures(Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain. The structure marked as 'A' can be identified as thesuperior cerebellar artery as it arises from the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries(marked as B).

The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum. The branches from this anastomosis supply diffrent parts of the brain.

The posterior communicating artery forms the link between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems by connecting the posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the basilar artery) with the internal carotid arteries. The anterior communicating artery connects the anterior cerebral arteries of the two sides (branches of the internal carotid artery).

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The diaphragmatic surface of the heart is shown below. Identify the structures marked X and Y.

choices.text: Posterior interventricular artery and middle cardiac vein
Posterior interventricular artery and small cardiac vein
Right coronary artery and middle cardiac vein
Left coronary artery and small cardiac vein

questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the posterior interventricular artery and the structure marked Y is the middle cardiac vein which can be identified as it drains into the coronary sinus. Both these structures lie in the posterior interventricular sulcus.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein(of Marshall) of the left atrium 

Related Pearl: Structures passing through heart sulci

questions.text: Which among the following marked cells are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells?
questions.solution:
The cells marked 'B' are the parafollicular cells/C-cells which are considered as members of amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells.

The C-cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have a pale staining cytoplasm, they are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the middle third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid and scattered in between the thyroid follicles. They are members of the APUD system of dispersed neuroendocrine cells. They secrete calcitonin which lowers blood calcium.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: The suprascapular nerveis the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

  • 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery
  • Supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trunks of Brachial plexus
  • Nerve to Serratus anterior
  • Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: Which among the following is the narrowest constriction of the ureter where a renal stone is most likely to be lodged?
questions.solution:
The stone is most likely to be lodged in the vesicoureteric junction marked as D in the image as it is the narrowest part of the ureter.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvi-ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Area marked A is Broca's Area (44, 45) and is present in the inferior frontal gyrus
Area marked B is the Visual Association Area (17, 18) and is present around the calcarine sulcus
Area marked C is the Motor Association area (5, 6) and is found in the superior parietal lobule
Area marked D is the Frontal Eye Field (8) and is found in the middle frontal gyrus

questions.solution:
Area marked D is the Frontal Eye Field (8) and is located in the posterior part of the middle frontal gyrus. It controls the conjugate movements of the eyes. It is connected to the visual part of the occipital cortex. Lesions here cause loss of horizontal conjugate movements. 

The area marked A is Wernicke's Area (22) and is present with auditory association areas and the inferior parietal lobule. It is the sensory language area. Lesions here cause sensory aphasia. 

Broca's or the Motor speech area (44, 45) is present in the pars triangularis and pars opercularis in the inferior frontal gyrus. Lesions here cause motor aphasia. 

Area marked B is the Visual Association Area (18, 19) and is present surrounding the striate area. It controls the correlation of visual impulses with memory, recognition of objects seen, and depth perception. Lesions here produce visual agnosia. 

Area 17 is the Primary Visual Cortex or the visuosensory area, present around the post-calcarine sulcus. It is associated with reception and perception of isolated visual impressions of color, size form, motion, illumination, and transparency. Lesions here produce homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. 

The area marked C is the Sensory Association area (5, 7) and is found between the sensory and visual areas in the superior parietal lobule. It is responsible for stereognosis and sensory speech. Lesion here causes astereognosis and sensory aphasia.

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: The following image shows first cervical vertebra, superior view. Part of the bone marked as Number 7 gives attachment to:
questions.solution:
Part of bone (Atlas) marked as number 7 is posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

Atlas (C1)

Atlanto-occipital joint allowing head nodding up and down (like showing yes).

Atlanto-axial joint allow head turning side to side (like showing no).

Bony features: 

  • No body, No spinous process 
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 - anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 transverse process with lateral transverse foramen - through which vertebral vessels pass through

Important Attachments:

  • Anterior arch - anteriorly attached to the "anterior longitudinal ligament", posteriorly articulates with "facet of dens" 
  • Posterior arch - superior border attached to "atlantooccipital membrane", inferior border attached to "ligamentum flavum"

 Axis (C2)

Bony features: 

  • Cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen and bifid spine
  • Dens (odontoid process) project up to space left by "missing" body of C1

Clinical consideration

  • Stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - Anterior longitudinal, Posterior longitudinal, Ligamentum flavum and Interspinous ligament.
  • C1 compression fracture at multiple sites "Jefferson fracture" and C2 hyperextension fracture "hangman fracture".

Other options:

  • Ligamentum nuchae-the posterior tubercle provides attachment for ligamentum nuchae.

questions.text: A fresh high school graduate attended an Army recruitment drive but was rejected due to his flat foot. The primary ligament in his foot that is most likely responsible for this condition is the _______.
questions.solution:
A flat foot is caused due to the involvement of the spring ligament.

Pes planus or flat foot is caused to due the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and can be either congenital or acquired. Its causes include rupture of spring ligament, tarsal coalition, disruption of tibialis posterior tendon, tarsometatarsal arthritis, and hindfoot degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

It supports the head of the talus which if fails or is destroyed, leads to separation of the navicular and calcaneus, in turn allowing the talar head, the highest point of the arch, to descend and leading to a flat-foot deformity.

Other options:

Option B: The anterior talofibular ligament is the ankle sprain ligament because it is the one that is most often damaged when the ankle is rolled.

Option C: The posterior talofibular ligament functions to stabilize the ankle joint and subtalar joint. Injuries are rare to this ligament unless there is an ankle dislocation or subluxation.

Option D: The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilizes the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are most common when the ankle undergoes anunstable ankle fracture.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

questions.text: Unlocking of the knee is by:
questions.solution:
Unlocking of the knee is mediated by the popliteus muscle.

  • Unlocking of the knee joint: It is the lateral rotation of femur on tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of popliteus muscle.
  • Locking of the knee joint: When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis.

questions.text: Which of the following cells originate from Monocytes?
questions.solution:
Microglial cells are possibly derived from the circulating monocytes which migrate into the CNS during the late fetal and early postnatal life.

The cells derived from the circulating monocytes are: alveolar macrophages in the lungs, phagocytic cells in the lymph nodes, spleen and bone marrow, Kupffer cells in liver sinusoids, and microglial cells in the CNS.

Neuroglial cells found in the parenchyma of the brain and spinal cord are broadly classified as follows:

  • Macroglia cells of ectodermal origin (neuroectoderm) and include the astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and glioblasts.
  • Microglia cells of mesodermal origin.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy living near the sea mistakenly consumes pufferfish and complains of vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain with ascending paralysis, and eventually dies with respiratory failure. The toxin in this poisoning acts mainly on which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Puffer fish poisoning is caused by the toxin tetrodotoxin. This toxin acts mainly on the sodium channnels.

This toxin is also used to study the flow of ions across the various other individual channels by blocking sodium channels. For instance, the sodium channels are blocked by tetrodotoxin when it is applied to the outside of the cell membrane where the sodium activation gates are located.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman delivers a male baby at 28 weeks of gestation. The preterm neonate was diagnosed with respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following ions are present in the compound that is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Preterm babies develop respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to surfactant deficiency. The calcium ions are present in the pulmonary surfactant.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions. The most important components are the,

  • Phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine,
  • Surfactant apoproteins,
  • Calcium ions.

The surfactants reduce the surface tension in the alveoli. It increases lung compliance, which reduces the work of expanding the lungs during inspiration.

Related Pearl: Hyaline membrane disease

 Infant Respiratory Distress Syndrome(IRDS):

  • Surfactant deficiency is an important cause of Infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) also known as hyaline membrane disease develops in infants born before their surfactant system is functional.
  • In IRDS there is high surface tension in the lungs resulting in atelectasis.
  • During fetal life, Cl-  is secreted along with fluid by the pulmonary epithelial cells. At birth, there is a shift to Na+ reabsorption by these cells via ENaC and fluid is absorbed along with Na+.
  • Prolonged immaturity of ENaC contributes to pulmonary edema in IRDS.
  • Overproduction/ dysregulation of surfactant proteins can also lead to respiratory distress and is the cause of Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female sex worker is brought to the casualty following fever, altered mental status, headache, nausea, and vomiting. During the examination, it is seen that the pupils are irregular in shape and small in size. They do not respond to light reflex but respond well to accommodation reflex.  This finding occurs due to a defect in
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the near reflex is present, whereas the light reflex is absent. This is due to a defect in the tectum. This abnormal pupillary response is called Argyll Robertson pupil and is seen in neurosyphilis.

Pathway for light reflex

  • Afferent fibers travel from the retina to the optic nerve, optic chiasma, and terminate in the pretectal nucleus.
  • Internuncial fibers connect the pretectal nucleus with Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides.
  • Parasympathetic fibers arise from the Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides, travel along the oculomotor nerve, and relay in the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibers travel along short ciliary nerves to innervate sphincter pupillae.

Clinical correlate- Since internuncial fibers connect the pretectal nucleus with Edinger Westphal nuclei of both sides, consensual light reflex is seen.

Pathway for accommodation reflex

  • The afferent fibers travel from the retina to the optic nerve, optic chiasma, optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, and parastriate cortex. 
  • Impulses from the parastriate cortex are relayed to the Edinger Westphal nucleus of both sides via the occipito-mesencephalic tract and pontine centers.
  • From Edinger Westphal nucleus efferent travel along the third nerve and reach sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles.

Other abnormal pupillary reactions are:

  1. Amaurotic light reflex- On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.
  2. Efferent pathway defect- Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.
  3. Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil.-In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.
  4. Marcus Gunn pupil- The pupil dilates in response to light. It is the earliest indication of optic nerve damage.
  5. Adie’s tonic pupil. In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by post ganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: A newly joined trainee at the gymnasium was able to lift about 8 Kilograms of weight using both his upper limbs. When two more kilograms were added, he could not resist and had dropped the weight down. Which receptor and nerve fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight?

choices.text: Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber
Golgi tendon organ and Ia fiber

questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Here, in the scenario given, two types of physiological reflexes have happened.

  • Stretch reflex/myotatic reflex - This has been responsible for the ability to bear the initial 8 kgs of weight by the trainee.
  • Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex - When two more kgs have been added, this has brought the inhibition of motor neuron discharge to his muscles which are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ, carried by Ib afferents, leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text:
An elderly man underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity. He now presents to his physician with complaints of dizziness, fatigue, and tremors 2 hours after the ingestion of a carbohydrate-rich meal. His symptoms occur mainly due to
  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Small volume of food intake
  3. High osmotic load of food
  4. Increased release of insulin
  5. Increased release of glucagon
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with features of late dumping syndrome following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. This occurs due to an increased release of insulin and hypoglycemia.

Dumping syndrome occurs due to rapid gastric emptying. It is commonly seen following gastric surgeries. It can be divided into

  • Early dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestions of foods with a high osmotic load. Increased osmotic load in the intestine leads to the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract. Patients will develop hypovolemia and hypotension.
  • Late dumping syndrome- Occurs after ingestion of a large volume of meals and meals which are rich in carbohydrates. A large amount of glucose is absorbed from the intestine which leads to a rapid increase in blood sugar levels. This in turns results in increased release of insulin which causes hypoglycemia. 

The mainstay in the management of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. The patient is advised to have small volume, regular meals that are rich in protein, fat, and low in carbohydrates. Somatostatin analogue like octreotide is used in the management of intractable syndromes.

Related Pearl: Early Dumping vs. Late Dumping

 

Early dumping

Late dumping

Incidence

5–10%

5%

Relation to meals

Almost immediate

Second hour after meal

Duration of attack

30–40 mins

30–40 mins

Relief

Lying down

Food

Aggravated by

More food

Exercise

Precipitating factor

Carbohydrate-rich food

Carbohydrate-rich food

Major symptoms

Epigastric fullness, sweating, light headedness, tachycardia, colic, sometimes diarrhoea

Tremor, faintness, prostration

questions.text:
A known amount of heavy water and inulin are injected intravenously into a healthy young male. The volume of distribution of heavy water and inulin are 36 liters and 12 liters respectively. Which of the following estimations is true about this condition?
  1. Total body water is 36L
  2. Intracellular fluid volume is 12L
  3. Extracellular fluid volume is 9L
  4. Plasma volume is 3L
  5. Volume of interstitial fluid is 6L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario total body water of the person is around 36L and plasma volume is around 3L.

Step 1- Find volumes of total body water and ECF. Heavy water measures the total body water whereas inulin measures the extracellular fluid (ECF). Therefore in this person, total body water is 36L and the ECF volume is 12L.

Step 2- Calculate intracellular fluid (ICF). ICF = total body water- ECF. Therefore ICF volume in this person is 24 L

Step 3- Calculate the plasma volume and volume of the interstitial fluid. Interstitial fluid constitutes three fourth of the ECF and plasma volume constitutes one-fourth of ECF. Therefore the volume of plasma is 1/4th of 12L which is 3L and the volume of interstitial fluid is 3/4th of 12L which is 9L

Related Pearl: Indicators for measurement of body fluids

Compartments

Indicators

Plasma volume
  • Evans’ blue(T1824)
  • Human serum albumin tagged with radioactive iodine125

RBC volume

Tagging RBC with cr-51, Fe-59, 32P, also antigenic tagging

ECF volume

  • Sucrose
  • Mannitol
  • Sodium thiosulphate
  • Sodium thiocyanate

Interstitial fluid

Cannot be measured directly.

ECF minus plasma volume gives the value

ICF

Cannot be measured directly.

TBW minus ECF gives the value (D2O minus Mannitol)

TBW

D2O (2H2O)

Tritium oxide (3H2O)

Antipyrine

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. If the compliance of the lung in Pulmonary fibrosis  is represented by curve C, what could curves A and B  most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Curves A and B will represent a normal lung and emphysema respectively.

  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance.
  • Curve A represents the normal compliance of the lungs. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve C, meaning that it takes greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve B is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).
  • Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.
  • Compliance is increased in emphysema due to the following.

The difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed hysteresis. The surfactant help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contributing to hysteresis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: The following is an RBC from venous blood. Identify the ? in the image.
questions.solution:
Cl- ion is exchanged for HCO3- across the RBC membrane.

The diagram explains the chloride shift that occurs in an RBC of venous blood as it carries CO2 to the lungs. This shift is mediated by an anion exchanger called AE 1 (Band 3). When this occurs, the osmolality inside an RBC is increased due to the chloride ions. This causes RBCs to absorb more water and swell up which accounts for the increased PCV in venous blood compared to the arterial blood.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic
    anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size.

questions.text: A physiologist studies about the sensor which detects elevated sodium and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the following structures acts as this sensor?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 'A' is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule and they act as the sensor in the process of tubuloglomerular feedback.

The given image constitutes the juxtaglomerular apparatus and has the following parts

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle form the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. They are marked as 'C' in the given image.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure. They are denoted by 'B' in the given image.

The structure marked as 'D' in the given image is the proximal tubular cell. It is involved in the process of glomerulotubular balance. 

When an increase in the GFR occurs, there is a consequential increase in the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule. This process is called as the glomerulotubular balance and it keeps the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes at constant levels.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point C.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled IV traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.solution:
Estrogen acts through nuclear receptors.

The rest of the hormones in the options act through GPCRs via the cAMP second messenger pathway, which is seen in the image.
