questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

Note: 

The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory.

However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitary

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is glycine.

Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of negative feedback inhibition.The axon of a spinal motor neuron gives a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. This inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

The Renshaw cell releases glycine to reduce the activity of the motor neuron.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least total cross-sectional area?
questions.solution:
Aorta has the least total cross-sectional area (4.5 cm2) and capillaries have the maximum cross-sectional area (4500 cm2).

In the circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the aorta. The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to the vascular cross-sectional area.

v= velocity
F= blood flow through the vessel
A=vascular cross-sectional area.

Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is highest in aorta and least in capillaries.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) lead eventually to downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsoption of water, despite high serum ADH levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. 

SIADH:

SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. Excessive ADH acts on renal V2 receptors to increase free water retention, therefore only H2O is reabsorbed and not solutes making the urine concentrated (UNa >40 and Uosm >100) and the serum dilute producing hyponatremia.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin. 

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increase in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are sloughed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Inflammatory cytokines
  • Iron

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis

Mutation in hepcidin causes Hereditary hemochromatosis. Secondary hemochromatosis can also occur due to the suppression of hepatic hepcidin production in diseases associated with ineffective erythropoiesis, such as β-thalassemia major and myelodysplastic syndrome.

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except?
questions.solution:
Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

Hemangioblastomas are tumors of CNS that originate from vascular tissues. They demonstrate the proliferation of capillaries with variable sized, closely packed, and thin walled vessels as seen in the image below:

Small round blue cell tumor consists of small round cells that stain blue on routine H&E staining sections:

  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor
  • Rhabdomyosarcomas
  • Acute leukemias

The following image is of Neuroblastoma showing small round blue cells:

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the following image?

choices.text: It is a remnant of microtubules
It can be seen in lead poisoning
It is specific to megaloblastic anemia
It is seen in some cases of megaloblastic anemia

questions.solution: The marked structure in this peripheral smear is a Cabot ring. It can be seen in megaloblastic anemia, post-splenectomy patients, lead poisoning and in some cases of hemolytic anemias; hence, it is not specific to megaloblastic anemia. It is considered as a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient, presented with a history of abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor for which CD117 is the specific marker.

  • Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen,
  • Most common site - stomach
  • The cell of origin - Interstitial cells of Cajal, or pacemaker cells, of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.
  • Peak age - 50-60 years
  • Carney triad -  gastric GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma
  • Carney- Stratakis syndrome- Loss of SDH function – GIST and paraganglioma
  • Approximately 75% to 80% of all GISTs - Gain-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT
  • Approximately 8% of GISTs have mutations that activate a PDGFRA.
  • The prognosis correlates with tumor size, mitotic index, and location
  • Gastric GISTs are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine.
  • Histological types- Spindle cell and epithelioid cell types.
  • Positive stains - CD117 / c-kit, CD34, DOG1, vimentin

questions.text: In Kawasaki disease, the following manifestation appears at:
questions.solution:
The above image shows desquamation of skin from fingers and toes. Desquamation of skin from fingers and toes occurs in the subacute phase (2 – 4 weeks) of Kawasaki disease.

Clinical phase of Kawasaki disease Duration Clinical feature
Acute febrile phase 1-2 weeks Fever, erythema
Subacute 2-4 weeks Desquamation and peeling of fingers and toes onset of coronary artery aneurysm
High risk of sudden death
Convalescence 6-8 weeks Recovery

questions.text: A 32 year old female with history of back ache and polyarthralgia was investigated and found to have nucleolar pattern in IF. Which of the following is the best fit in her case.

choices.text: Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.solution:
The nucleolar pattern in IF indicates Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly to be the best fit in the given case.

Nuclear pattern in immunofluorescence:

The nucleolar pattern indicates some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. The pattern is most often seen in systemic sclerosis(sclerodactyly) which has a female:male ratio of 3:1.


In limited sclerodactyly patients develop a combination of Calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia called the CREST syndrome. 


Patients with this syndrome have relatively limited involvement of skin(which a great majority of Sclerodactyly patients have), often confined to fingers, forearms, and face, and calcification of the subcutaneous tissues. Involvement of the viscera may not occur at all or occur late. In general, these patients live longer than those with systemic sclerosis with diffuse visceral involvement at the outset.

questions.text: The granules shown in the image are seen in the cytoplasm of________
questions.solution:
The given image shows Birbeck granules, which are in the cytoplasm of Langerhans cells.

They are pentalaminar tubules often with a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket like appearance, which contain protein langerin. Although a part of normal Langerhans histology they also provide a mechanism to differentiate Langerhans cell histocytes from other proliferative cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with weakness of the left upper limb. On examination, the blood pressure recorded on the left upper limb was found to be lower than that of the right upper limb. Her aortic arch angiogram showed narrowing of the arch of the aorta and subclavian artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It involves the arch of the aorta and its branches, usually the subclavian artery, leading to reduced blood pressure and weak pulse in the affected upper limb.

Takayasu arteritis is a chronic inflammatorymedium- and large-vessel vasculitisthat commonly affects adolescents andyoung females.Itmainly involves theaortic archand its branches. Depending on the artery occluded, patients present with the following symptoms:

  • Subclavian artery(most common) -pain, numbness,claudication, andweak or absent radial pulseson the affected side
  • Common carotid artery - visualsymptoms, syncope, and stroke
  • Abdominal aorta, superior mesenteric artery, and coeliac axis -abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Renal artery -hypertensionand renal failure
  • Aortic arch or root - aortic insufficiency, heart failure
  • Pulmonary artery - atypical chest pain, dyspnea
  • Coronary artery - chest pain, myocardial infarction
  • Iliac artery - Legclaudication, weak/absent pulses in the periphery

Patients also have constitutional symptoms such as malaise, fever, night sweats, weight loss, etc.

Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels.Arteriographyis done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includesglucocorticoidtherapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery of the stenosed vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Nerve involvement results in mononeuritis multiplex. Depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Option D: Kawasaki disease is an acute self-limiting illness affecting medium-sized arteries in children less than 4 years of age. Coronary arteries are affected which may cause aneurysm, thrombosis or myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Which of the following heart tumours exhibit the histologic pattern as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shoes abundant spider cells. They are seen in Rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane, an appearance referred to as “spider” cells.

 Rhabdomyoma:

  • Most frequent primary tumor of the pediatric heart
  • 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumor-suppressor genes TSC1 and TSC2.
  • Usually multiple and prefer ventricles preferentially
  • Often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas

 

Image: Spider cell in rhabdomyoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from eastern parts of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy shows granulomas and findings as seen below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous Leishmaniasis

Cutaneous leishmaniasis is a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions.

Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with Leishmania.

questions.text: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) affects CD4 cells due to interaction of the protein  __________
questions.solution:
The CD4 cells are affected by HIV due to their interaction with gp120.

Structure of HIV:

HIV-1 virion is spherical and contains an electron-dense, cone-shaped core surrounded by a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane.

The virus core contains (1) the major capsid protein p24; (2) nucleocapsid protein p7/p9; (3) two copies of viral genomic RNA; and (4) the three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase). The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virion envelope.

The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which are critical for HIV infection of cells.

Pathogenesis:

  • Target cells of HIV: include CD4+ helper T cells (worst affected), monocyte-macrophages, and dendritic cells.
  • Viral glycoprotein gp120 binds to CD4+ cells in the host.
  • This binding leads to a conformational change causing exposure of a new recognition site gp41 for the co-receptors.
  • CXCR4 and CCR5 function as coreceptors for HIV-1 entry into CD4+ cells.
  • The virus then fuses with the host cell membrane.
  • gp41: Fusion peptide at the tip inserts into the cell membrane of the target cells (e.g., T cells or macrophages), leading to the fusion of the virus with the host cell.

 

The image below shows the pathogenesis of HIV infection:

questions.text: Given below is the histological slide demonstrating a renal pathology. Which of the following would be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, sometimes filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

  • Acute tubular necrosis: Focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis
  • Minimal change disease: Normal on light microscopy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Wire-loop lesions

questions.text: The deformity depicted here is:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity.

Option B: Deviated nose - Midline is straight but deviated to one side.

 

Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum.

Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ethmoidal polyp?

choices.text: It is usually seen in children

questions.solution:
Allergy is the main etiological factor for ethmoidal polyp.

It is usually multiple, bilateral, and more common in middle-aged individuals.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: Which among the following is the best test for ET function?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is an objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation.

Procedure: Movement of TM is visualized to variation in external canal pressure

Shortcoming: Middle ear pathologies will overshadow ET function.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of organ of Corti?
questions.solution:
Organ of Corti is derived from the otic vesicle which forms from the ectoderm.

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

questions.text: All of the following are features of sinus fungal ball except

choices.text: It is caused by A. fumigatus and A. flavus
Presence of calcification in sinus on CT
Fungal elements accumulate to form an expansile mass

questions.solution:
Sinus fungal ball usually presents as unilateral rhinosinusitis (and not bilateral).

Features of sinus fungal ball:

  • It is seen in immunocompetent hosts and is commonly caused by Aspergillus fumigatus orAspergillus flavusand has excellent prognosis.
  • Clinical features include
    • unilateral rhinosinusitis.
    • nasal obstruction.
    • green-brown nasal discharge
  • Histopathology reveals dense accumulation of fungal elements in a mucoid matrix forming an expansile mass.
  • CT revealscalcification in the involved sinus (maxillary sinus commonly).
  • Treatment of sinus fungal ball includes debridement of the involved tissues. Antifungals are usually not required for the treatment.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
The image shows Battle's sign.

It is retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

Other options:

Option b: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

Option c: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

Option d: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.solution: Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

questions.text: All of the following are complications of  Diphtheria except:
questions.solution:
Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria. 

Exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes

  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute circulatory failure. 

In the larynx, diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Neurological complications are paralysis of soft-palate, diaphragm and ocular muscles.

questions.text: Which among the following finding is predominantly seen in the layer of retina highlighted below?
questions.solution:
The highlighted layer given in the image is the outer plexiform layer (identified as it lies between two nuclear layers). Hard exudates mostly occur in this layer.

Hard Exudates - extravasation of fluid rich in fibrin and protein around the area of microaneurysms. They mostly occur in the outer plexiform layer. They appear as well defined bright yellow deposits.

Soft Exudates  -  also known as ‘cotton wool spots’ occur due to the accumulation of cellular debris that occurs as a result of ischemia. They are seen in the nerve fiber layer. They appear as ill-defined, cloud-like soft aggregates with feathery margins.

Flame haemorrhages -  It is due to the rupture of blood vessels in the nerve fiber layer. They assume flame shape because of the collection of blood in between the parallel running nerve fibers.

Drusen - are extracellular deposits located in the interface between retinal pigmentary epithelium and Bruch membrane.

The following image shows different layers of retina.

 

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina (outer to inner)

  • Rods and cones
  • External limiting membrane
  • Outer nuclear layer
  • Outer plexiform layer
  • Inner nuclear layer
  • Inner plexiform layer
  • Ganglion cell layer
  • Nerve fibre layer
  • Internal limiting membrane

questions.text: The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of hexagonal cells lying between

choices.text: Ganglion cell layer and nerve fibre layer

questions.solution:
The retinal pigment epithelium consists of a single layer of hexagonal cells lying between the layer of rods and cones (photoreceptor) and Bruch’s membrane.

Pigment epithelium:

  • Provides metabolic support to the neurosensory retina
  • Acts as an antireflective layer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities are not a feature of background diabetic retinopathy. They are seen in the Preproliferative diabetic retinopathy stage.

Background diabetic retinopathy is a collective term used to describe the earliest changes in diabetic retinopathy. 

 

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions present with Horner Trantas dots?
questions.solution:
Horner Trantas dots are seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They appear as white dots at the limbus of the cornea. These white dots contain eosinophils and epithelial cellular debris.

Other options:

  • Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis: 
    • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction 
    • Due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • Characterized by the following:
      • Phlycten
      • May eventually form ring ulcers
      • Scrofulous ulcer: shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten
      • Fascicular ulcer: It has a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels. It heals leaving a band-shaped opacity.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis:
    • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
    • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
    • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.
  • Lyell syndrome: It is a form of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

questions.text: A patient presented with diplopia. On examination, pupils was dilated. Both direct and consensual light reflexes were lost in the affected eye. The diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that the patient has III nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy.

Absence of contraction of the pupil in both direct and consensual reflex suggests a lesion in the efferent pathway of the affected eye. This is III nerve/oculomotor palsy.

Light reflex consists of direct and consensual reflexes.

When light is shone in an eye,

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex

For the light reflex,

  • Afferent nerve fiber is the II cranial nerve (optic nerve).
  • Efferent nerve fiber is the III cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve)-Bilaterally

 In II nerve palsy, there will be a loss of direct reflex in the affected eye and loss of consensual light reflex in the opposite eye.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant.

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. 
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. 

The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below:

Features Comitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive.

Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a foreceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

questions.text: A 25-year-old contact lens user presents with complaints of mucopurulent discharge from his left eye associated with photophobia. Slit-lamp examination of his tarsal conjunctiva shows circular red elevations with apical infiltrates. Which of the following term is used to describe this slip lamp finding?
questions.solution:
The term 'papillae' is used to describe the abovesaid slit-lamp finding.

The presence of papillae is one of the clinical signs of conjunctivitis. It has the following features

  • They are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium. Hence, they appear as red elevations.
  • Infiltrates represent the cells recruited to the site of inflammation, and they typically accompany a papillary response.
  • Size less than 1mm is macropapilla; whereas the size of greater than 1mm is the giant papilla.
  • Causes for this include bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, chronic blepharitis, and wearing contact lenses.

Follicles: They are multiple, discrete, yellowish-white, round elevations, 1-2 mm in diameter. They are due to localised aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. Follicles are most prominent in the fornices. The common causes are viral and chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Chemosis: It is used to describe the conjunctival oedema

Granulomas: They are fleshy sessile or pedunculated lesions with inflammatory tissue. They usually result from some form of chronic local irritation such as a foreign body. 

The following images show the papillae and follicles respectively.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with 3 years history of on & off moderate non-foul-smelling ear discharge complaints of poor hearing which improves during periods of discharge but is worse when the ear is dry. This paradoxical phenomenon can be explained by _____
questions.solution:
The patient is a case of CSOM and tubotympanic disease.

Round window-shielding effect is seen in tubotympanic disease, where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase, (no discharge), sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is better when the ear is discharging.

Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.

questions.text: Which of the following bones does not form the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
The frontal process of the maxilla does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum. It forms the bony skeleton of the external nose.

The bony part of the external nose consists of

  • Two nasal bones
  • Frontal process of maxilla lateral to nasal bones on each side.
  • Nasal process of the frontal bone in the midline between 2 nasal bones.
  • Nasion is the site of the junction of nasal bone with the nasal process of the frontal bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a core histone?
questions.solution:
H2A, H2B, H3 and H4 are called core histones. They form octamers made up of two units of each core histone. DNA is wrapped around this octamer to form a nucleosome.

H1 histones stabilise 30 nm chromatin fibres made up of six to seven supercoiled nucleosomes.

questions.text: Lipoprotein lipase is not active in?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein lipase is not active in the adult liver. This prevents the degradation of chylomicrons and VLDL in the liver. Instead, the liver has hepatic lipase that is involved in the degradation of chylomicron remnants and HDL.

Lipoprotein lipase is found in the heart, lung, adipose tissue, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, lactating mammary gland and spleen.

questions.text: The oxygen debt seen after exercise is due to?
questions.solution:
Oxygen debt seen after exercise is due to increased gluconeogenesis.

In exercise, anaerobic glycolysis takes place and the lactate formed enters the gluconeogenic pathway in the liver. Regeneration of a glucose molecule from lactate requires 6 ATPs whereas the ATP provided by anaerobic glycolysis is only 2 per molecule of glucose. This energy gap is met through oxidative phosphorylation and the oxygen consumed in the process makes up the oxygen debt.

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease. 

Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Maltese cross appearance is as follows:

Maltese cross appearance elsewhere:

  • Short-range shotgun wound
  • Babesiosis

  • Red blood cell casts: Glomerular causes
  • White blood cells casts: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy brown casts: Acute tubular necrosis, interstitial nephritis
  • Fatty casts: Heavy proteinuria
  • Broad casts: Chronic renal failure

questions.text: Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect specific sequences of DNA?
questions.solution:
Southern blot transfer technique can be used to detect specific sequences of DNA. It involves the following steps.

  • DNA from a cell line or tissue is digested into fragments by restriction enzymes
  • The fragments are embedded in agarose or polyacrylamide gel and subjected to electrophoresis. This separates the fragments based on their charge and size
  • The electrophoresed fragments are then denatured with a mild alkali and transferred to nitrocellulose or nylon paper
  • A labelled DNA probe is added, which hybridizes with complementary strands of DNA
  • The hybridisation is visualised by X-raying the film or using an image screen

Other options:

  • Western blot is used to detect and quantify specific protein molecules
  • Northern blot is used to detect and quantify specific RNA molecules
  • South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions

questions.text: Fructose 2, 6 bisphosphate is an allosteric regulator. Which of the following is true about fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate?

choices.text: Formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by Phosphofructokinase-1
Fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
Among the given options, 'fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels favours gluconeogenesis' is the correct option.

This is a tandem enzyme and has the activity of both phosphofructokinase-II (PFK II) and fructose 2,6 bis phosphatase. 

  • PFK-II converts fructose 6 phosphate to fructose 2,6 bisphosphate. 
  • Fructose 2,6 bis-phosphatase converts fructose 2,6 bisphosphate to fructose 6 phosphate. 

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate allosterically activates PFK -I, which is involved in converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate in glycolysis. Hence, fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate acts as an intracellular signal, indicating that glucose is abundant and hence causes an increase in the rate of glycolysis during the well-fed state. 

Whereas, during fasting, there is the phosphorylation of this tandem enzyme by glucagon. This phosphorylation causes the inactivation of PFK-II part and activation of Fructose 2,6 bis-phosphatase component. As a result of this, there is a fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels. This favours gluconeogenesis.  

Other options:

Option A: Fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate is formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-2.

Option B: Fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate is the most potent positive allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase-1.

Option D: Fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate is an inhibitor of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphatase.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis inferred from the given clinical images is?
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is associated with the classic clinical triad of diarrhoea, alopecia and a periorificial and acral cutaneous eruption.

  • Zinc deficiency can be inherited (acrodermatitis enteropathica) or acquired.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene,SLC39A4, found on chromosome 8q24.3, which leads to deficiency of zinc.
  • Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges.
  • The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a ‘Ushaped’ or ‘horseshoeshaped’ appearance.
  • Zinc supplementation rapidly improves the condition within 24 to 48 hours. If untreated, it maybe fatal.

Remember Mnemonic: DEAL for Acrodermatitis enteropathica

D – Diarrhoea

E – Eczematous dermatitis

A - Alopecia

L – Lethargy

questions.text: What level of structural organization of a protein is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures viz:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein.

questions.text: The following image shows the normal electrophoresis of serum proteins. Which of the following bands is much prominent in nephrotic syndrome ?
questions.solution:
The band that is marked as C in the given image corresponds to α2 globulin. This band becomes much prominent in nephrotic syndrome.

α2  macroglobulin, being a relatively bigger protein compared to others is not lost through urine in nephrotic syndrome. Hence the α2 band which includes α2 macroglobulin is very prominent in serum protein electrophoresis of a nephrotic syndrome patient.

The following image shows the bands with their corresponding proteins in normal serum electrophoresis.

questions.text: A Biochemist while studying the granules present in the mononuclear cells shown in the below image noticed the presence of glycosaminoglycans. Which of the following repeating sugars are present in the identified glycosaminoglycan?
questions.solution:
Heparin is the glycosaminoglycan present in the granules of the given mononuclear cell / mast cell. The repeating units found in this are Glucosamine + Iduronic acid.

Heparin is an important anticoagulant. It is present in the liver, lungs, spleen, and monocytes. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase.

questions.text: A young chemist notices a reaction system in which the rate of conversion of substrates to product is equal to the rate at which products are converted back to substrates. Which of the following properties regarding this reaction system is true?

choices.text: The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rates
The rate constants  of the forward and backward reactions are equal
The value of equilibrium constant increases with increase in catalyst or enzyme concentration

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Equilibrium is a dynamic state is the correct option.

In an equilibrium state, Although there is no net change in the concentration of substrates or products, individual substrate, and product molecules are continually being interconverted and hence it is said to be dynamic.

Some important properties of a system at equilibrium are:

  • The equilibrium constant (Keq) is a ratio of the reaction rate constants (not the reaction rates). 
  • At equilibrium, the reaction rates (not the rate constants) of the forward and back reactions are equal. 
  • The numerical value of the constant can be calculated by finding the concentrations of substrates and products.
  • If Keq is more than 1, the forward reaction is favoured. In such instances, the reaction is spontaneous and exothermic.
  • The concentration of the enzyme does not affect the Keq. The concentration of enzyme certainly increases the rate of reaction; but not the Keq or the ultimate state. Catalysts increase the rate of reaction but do not alter the equilibrium.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with the history of polyuria and polydipsia was diagnosed to be suffering from type 1 DM. What will be the effect of this condition on the free fatty acid(FFA) level in this boy?

choices.text: Decreased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to Low glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Decreased FFA level due to low glucagon: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
In type I diabetes mellitus, there is an Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state and hence glucagon: insulin ratio will be high. The level of FFA, in turn, is controlled by glucagon:insulin ratio. Glucagon increases the FFA level and insulin has the opposite effect.

Note: Low insulin state also causes increased fatty acid oxidation leading to increased ketone body production and ketosis.

questions.text: The pentose phosphate pathway is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. Which enzyme does not contribute in the reversible phase of this pathway?
questions.solution:
6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible , oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway or the HMP shunt.

While Keto-isomerase, Transketolase, Transaldolase and Phosphohexose isomerase have a role in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway or HMP shunt  is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose.
It does not lead to the formation of ATP, but it has two major functions:

  • Formation of NADPH
  • Synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate

There are 2 phases in the HMP pathway: Oxidative and non oxidative.

  •  Oxidative is irreversible.
  •  non-oxidative is a reversible reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following region of mRNA offers protection from 3  5 exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.  Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.

Other options:

Option A: The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

Option B: TATA box is the site of pre-initiation complex formation, which is the first step in transcription initiation.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about displacement reactions is false?

choices.text: A group is transferred from one substrate to another
Each reaction has two Km values
Enzymes are transiently modified in single displacement reactions

questions.solution:
Enzymes are transiently modified in double displacement reactions.

Displacement reactions involve the transfer of a group between two substrates. The reactions can take place in a single step or in two steps.

A single step reaction involves the direct transfer of a group between two substrates bound to an enzyme. Such reactions are called sequential or single displacement reactions. In a two step reaction, the group is first transferred to the enzyme and then to the second substrate. These reactions are called double displacement reactions.

Each substrate has its own Km value and most of the displacement reactions follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

questions.text: A baker uses artificial colours and flavour additives in his bakery goods. Which metalloprotein is responsible for the metabolism of these substances?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome P450 is involved in the metabolism of flavour/colour additives which are examples of xenobiotics.

Hydroxylation of xenobiotics is done by Cytochrome P450.

The members of the cytochrome P450 family generate Fe = O3+. This is a powerful oxidant that participates in the reduction and neutralization of a broad range of xenobiotics via the two-electron reduction of O2.

Cytochrome P450:

Cytochromes P450 are an important superfamily of heme-containing monooxygenases. They are located mainly in the endoplasmic reticulum in the liver and intestine but are also found in the mitochondria in some tissues. It is involved in a series of enzymatic reactions known as the hydroxylase cycle.

A primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about expected frequency (EF) in Chi-square test.

choices.text: It is the frequency that is expected when the null hypothesis is true
Chi square test can be used only if all EF values are >5 in a 2 x 2 table
For 3 x 3 tables, at least 20% of the EF values have to be <5
If observed frequency is equal to expected frequency, null hypothesis is true

questions.solution:
For tables greater than 2 x 2, not more than 20% of the expected frequency values should be <5. Otherwise, the Chi-square test is not valid.

Expected frequency is defined as the frequency one would find when the null hypothesis is true.

This can be understood with an example:


 Drug A Drug B Total
Patients cured 12 4 16
Patients uncured 8 16 24
Total 20 20 40

In the table, you can see two drugs being compared. Let’s find the expected frequency for patients cured using drug A.

Assume the null hypothesis is true. This would mean drugs A and B have the same cure rate.

In this example, since 16 out of 40 people got cured, the cure rate is 16/40.

The expected cure frequency for drug A users is calculated as follows

Expected cure frequency =   cure rate x no of patients using drug A

= (16/40) x 20

= 8

You can see that the expected cure frequency of 8 is different from the observed cure frequency of 12.

Likewise, observed drug B cure frequency is 4 against an expected frequency of 8.

These differences are used in calculating the Chi-square test statistic and rejecting the null hypothesis

 

If there is no difference between the observed and expected frequency, the Chi square test statistic has a value of zero and the null hypothesis is true.

For 2 x 2 tables, the expected frequency values must be >5 for the Chi-square test to be applied.

For tables greater than 2 x 2, the expected frequency must be > 1 for all variables and not more than 20% of the variables should be < 5.

Use: It is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

questions.text: Blue baby syndrome can be prevented when the levels of nitrates and nitrites in drinking water are respectively less than:
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia caused by the decreased ability of blood to carry vital oxygen around the body manifests as blueness around mouth, hands, and feet and is thus known as “blue baby syndrome”.

The most common cause of methemoglobinemia is the high levels of nitrates in drinking water.

High levels of nitrate may be due to intensive farming practices with excess use of fertilizers. The group at the highest risk are bottle-fed infants.

Control of nitrate and nitrites respectively below 50 mg /litre and 3mg/litre is an effective preventive measure.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters

 

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, there should be no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU for household drinking water.  Expressed in nephelometric turbidity units (NTU). It describes the cloudiness of water. >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye. <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, there should be no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU. Expressed in true color units (TCU). >15 TCU is detectable by naked eye. 
Taste and odor No health based guideline value has been proposed. It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. The cause must be investigated.
Temperature No health based guideline value has been proposed. Cool water is generally more palatable. High water temperature may enhance the growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters

  Guideline values Comments
Ammonia No health based guideline value has been proposed as it occurs in drinking water at concentrations well below those of health concern. Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium 0.9 mg/l There is very less evidence that aluminium in drinking water causes toxic effects.
Arsenic 0.01 mg/l Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride 250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears. Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/litre. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper 2 mg/l Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects and other adverse effects in people without normal copper homeostasis.
Fluoride 1.5 mg/l Above this guideline value, there is risk of dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis. Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre. A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent against methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects in susceptible populations  This guideline
value is based on the absence of adverse health effects (methaemoglobinaemia
and thyroid effects) at concentrations below 50 mg/L in epidemiological studies.
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent against methemoglobinemia in infants and the general population. Bottle-fed infant are at higher risk.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5. ______
Lead 0.01 mg/l The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury 0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury Nephrotoxicity is the main effect of mercury toxicity.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Benzo(a)pyrene at 0.0007 mg/l They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic.
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give unacceptable taste. _________
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable. TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • They include a range of aerobic and facultative anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming bacilli capable of fermenting lactose to acid or aldehyde at 35 to 37 degree Celsius within 24 hours. They include fecal and environmental organisms from wide genera.
    • E. coli and thermotolerant coliforms are a subset of the total coliform groups and they ferment lactose at 44 – 45 degrees Celsius and have the ability to produce indole.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci:
      • They are used as an indicator of fecal pollution.
      • Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens:
      • They are spore-forming organisms which are resistant to many disinfection methods.
      • They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination.
      • Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process and of the presence of other contaminants in the water.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts are indicators of disinfection and distribution of water. It measures a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidences of fecal contamination of water.

 

IV) Radiological aspects

  • Becquerel (Bq) is the unit used for radioactivity.
  • In the case of drinking water, the concentration of radioactivity is referred to as Bq/litre.
  • Proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: Tracking of dropouts and left outs by card tracing and vaccinating them per complete coverage is done by?
questions.solution:
It is the duty of the female health worker to track dropouts and left outs under the Universal Immunization Program (UIP) and vaccinate them per complete coverage.

While the Male health worker has a role under the expanded programme on immunization, it does not involve tracking of dropouts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Aedes albopictus is a vector for Zika virus transmission. Aedes aegypti is also a vector for zika virus.

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus and the infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise.

A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations. Petechial rashes are not seen.

Complications: Guillian-Barre syndrome and microcephaly and intracranial calcification in infants born to mothers infected with Zika virus. Pregnant women should consider postponing travel to areas where Zika virus transmission is ongoing.

Diagnosis:  

  • Trioplex Real-Time RT-PCR (rRT-PCR) assay
  •  Zika MAC-ELISA.

questions.text: Chandler's Index is used in epidemiological studies of _____
questions.solution:
Chandler's index is used to identify the importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem in a community. It is calculated based on the average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool:

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

questions.text: A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with:

choices.text: Mean of 1 and a standard deviation of 0
Mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

questions.solution:
A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

  • Normal distribution is the most widely used continuous distribution.
  • It is also called bell curve (bell shaped) or Gaussian distribution after a mathematician named Karl Friedrich Gauss.
  • The following is an image of three different types of normal distributions.
  • Normal distributions are defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation.
  • The mean, median and mode are all equal in a normal distribution.
  • All normal distributions are symmetric and have bell-shaped density curves with a single peak.
  • Exactly half of the values are to the left of the centre and the other half to the right.
  • The total area under the curve is 1.
  • The density of a normal distribution is more around the centre and less around the tails.
  • There is no skew in the curve.
  • Looking at the figure below, we can understand the empirical rule of a normal distribution which states that:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 1 SD).
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD).
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD).
  • Many data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution.
  • A standard normal distribution is a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

questions.text: All the following tests are used to check efficiency of pasteurization except:
questions.solution:
Methylene blue reduction test is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk.

The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization, not to check the efficiency of pasteurization.

Tests to check the efficiency of pasteurization:

  • Phosphatase test
  • Standard plate count
  • Coliform count

Methods of pasteurization:

  • Holder/Vat method: 63-66°C for 30 minutes
  • HTST method (High temp short time): 72°C for 15 seconds
  • UHT method (Ultra-high temp): 125 °C for a few seconds

questions.text: Which of the following is a population statistic?
questions.solution:
Sex ratio is a population statistic.

All others are vital statistics.

Demographic indicators have been divided into 2 parts:

  • Population statistics : includes population size, sex ratio, density, dependency ratio.
  • Vital statistics : includes birth rate, death rate, natural growth rate, life expectancy at birth, mortality rate, fertility rate.

Other options:

Crude birth rate

  • Birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/Estimated mid-year population

General Fertility Rate

  • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age in the same area in the same year.

Life Expectancy :

  • Life expectancy  is defined as  "the age to which a person is expected to live in a particular population if the current age-specific mortality rates persist".

Related Pearl: Sex Ratio

  • It is the number of females per 1000 males.
  • According to a census in 2011, the sex ratio in India was 940 females per 1000 males.
  • Kerala currently holds a favorable sex ratio with values of 1084 females per 1000 men.
  • The sex composition of the population is affected by the differentials in mortality conditions of males and females, sex-selective migration and the sex ratio at birth.
  • A very low sex ratio indicates male-child favoritism.

questions.text: If a study shows that among smokers, 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking, it is indicative of _________
questions.solution:
It is indicative of attributable risk.

Here, cigarette smoking is attributed to be the cause of 80% of lung cancers in smokers.

Other options:

Option A: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Relative and attributable risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR >1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ c/(c+d)] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: The Ujjwala yojana is for:

choices.text: Providing LPG connections to families below the poverty line
Improving the quality of labour rooms
Providing home based born care by ASHA

questions.solution:
The Ujjwala Yojana (note spelling without "a") is for providing 5 crore free cooking (LPG) connections to all families below the poverty line till 2019.

The Ujjawala Scheme is for prevention of trafficking and for rescue, rehabilitation and reintegration of victims of trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation.

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is related to Abhiyan Indradhanush?

choices.text: Maintaining peace and harmony among employees
Ensure complete vaccination in a newborn for all vaccine preventable diseases
Change of bed sheets on all 7 days of the week

questions.solution:
Abhiyan Indradhanush in relation to Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) pertains to change of bedsheets on a daily basis from Sunday to Saturday (VIBGYOR pattern for the color of bedsheet to be used) at ESIC hospitals.

Not to be confused with Mission Indradhanush, which is related to vaccination.

questions.text: The peripheral most centre out of the following options under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme structure is:
questions.solution: Among the options given, Peripheral health institution is the most peripheral.

questions.text: If sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%, calculate positive likelihood ratio:
questions.solution:
Sensitivity is 90% and Specificity is 95%.

Positive likelihood ratio: Sensitivity / 1-specificity = 18

The positive likelihood ratio is the likelihood of a diseased person being detected as positive is as compared to a normal person.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about par boiling?

choices.text: Parboiling refers to partial cooking of rice in steam
The hot soaking process is used for par boiling.
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm due to par boiling.
Par boiling softens the rice grains and makes it resistant to insects.

questions.solution:
Par boiling hardens the rice grains (not softens) and makes it resistant to insects.

Par boiling:

Par boiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam.

The hot soaking process is used for par boiling and it was developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

It preserves the nutritive quality of rice as during the process, vitamins and minerals in the outer aleurone layer are driven into inner endosperm.

The advantages are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality
  • Hardens the grains
  • Makes the rice grains insect resistant
