questions.text: Exposure to sound with a minimum level of _______ dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss
questions.solution:
Exposure to sound with a minimum level of 160 dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: Learned behavior which is socially acquired is known as?
questions.solution:
Culture:

  • Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired.

Culture is considered as the product of human societies and man is a product of his cultural environment. Cultural factors have an important role in health and disease as incidence of some disease are affected by customs and practices of different cultures.

Other options:

Option A  - Custom:

  • The established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting.

Option B - Acculturation: Is ‘cultural contact’ or mixing of two cultures. It can occur through:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Propagation of religion
  • Education
  • Conquest

Option C  - Standard of Living:

  • Refers to the usual scale of our expenditure, goods we consume and the services we enjoy.
  • Standard of living (WHO) includes: 
    • Income and Occupation
    • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
    • Level of provision of health, educational, recreational and other services

Folkways:

  • Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct.
  • Mores are stringent customs.

questions.text: Estimation of glycated hemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of:
questions.solution:
Estimation of glycated haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of secondary prevention.

Prevention and care in diabetes mellitus:

A. Primordial prevention: It involves the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in the countries in which they have not yet appeared.

B. Primary prevention: The scope of primary prevention in diabetes mellitus is currently limited. It involves the elimination of environmental risk factors. The preventive measures include:

  • Maintenance of normal body weight through the adoption of healthy nutritional habits and physical exercise.
  • The nutritional habits include an adequate protein intake, a high intake of dietary fibre and avoidance of sweet foods.
  • Elimination of other less well-defined factors such as protein deficiency and food toxins.

C. Secondary prevention: It involves preventive measures taken up after diabetes is detected. The aims of treatment include maintenance of normal blood sugar and maintenance of ideal body weight. The preventive measures include:

  • Routine checking of blood sugar, of urine for proteins and ketones, of blood pressure, visual acuity and weight.
  • Examination of feet for any defective blood circulation, loss of sensation and the health of the skin.
  • Estimation of glycated (glycosylated) haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals.
  • Self-care, which includes adherence to diet and drug regimens, the examination of his own urine and where possible blood glucose monitoring; self-administration of insulin, abstinence from alcohol, maintenance of optimum weight, attending periodic check-ups, recognition of symptoms associated with glycosuria and hypoglycaemia, etc.

D. Tertiary prevention: It involves limiting the disability occurring in patients with diabetes through its complications, e.g., blindness, kidney failure, coronary thrombosis, gangrene of the lower extremities, etc. The measures include:

  • Establishing specialized diabetic clinics to provide care of the highest order.
  • The clinics should be involved in basic, clinical, and epidemiological research.
  • Establishing local and national registries for diabetics.

questions.text: An HIV patient was found to have a CD4 count of 184 cells per microliter. Which of the following is used for prophylaxis against pneumocystis carinii infection?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is offered to HIV patients with CD4 below 200cells/μL as primary prophylaxis against P. carinii infection.

Alternatively, they can also be given aerosolized pentamidine or dapsone.

Patients who develop P.carinii infection on a particular prophylactic regimen should be switched to the other drug or should receive a combination regimen.

questions.text: 5 people out of 60 who landed from an international flight were positive for COVID-19. Totally, 75 people were in contact with these 5 cases, out of these 15 were found to be positive within 2 weeks of the incubation period. Calculate the secondary attack rate in this?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate, in this case, is 20%

In this scenario, the total number of primary cases were 5.

The total number exposed people who were in contact with the primary cases were 75and the total number of exposed people developing the disease were 15.

Secondary attack rate=(Number of exposed people developing the disease within the incubation period/Number of people exposed)100

=(15/75)100

=(1/5)x100

=20

Therefore the secondary attack rate is 20%

Note:

The incubation period of COVID-19 may extend up to 14 days, with a median incubation period between 4-5 days from exposure to symptoms onset.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Incidence rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time ) x 1000

Incidence rate of spells of sickness = ( Number of spells of sickness starting in a specified period /Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time ) x 1000

Attack rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time /Total population at risk during the given time ) x 100

Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period/Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts ) x 100

Prevalence = ( Number of all cases (new+old) of a specified disease at a given point in time/ Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

questions.text: A family consisting of a husband and a pregnant wife, along with 2 daughters aged 7 and 9 years, they stay in a house with 2 rooms. According to the accepted standards with respect to overcrowding, which of the following is false?

choices.text: The floor space of the house should be >110 sq ft
The house of this family is overcrowded
The family requires at least two rooms

questions.solution:
This family does not live in overcrowding presently. 

As children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit, this family is counted as 3 units (husband+wife+daughter+daughter= 1+1+0.5+0.5=3), who are living in 2 rooms, which is in accordance with the accepted standards.

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards of persons per room against overcrowding are as follows.

No of rooms  No of persons/units
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
5 rooms 10 persons (1 room for every 2 additional persons)

The floor space standards against overcrowding are as follows.

Area No of persons/units
110 sq. ft. and more 2 persons
90 – 100 sq. ft. 1 ½ person (Children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit)
70 – 90 sq. ft. 1 person
50 – 70 sq. ft. ½ person

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both LBW and Normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of Oral Hypoglycemic agents during the 1st trimester to determine the association of "LBW" and "OHA intake in the first trimester". Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Odds ratio calculation (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who works in a glass manufacturing industry comes with complaints of abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and blueline on the gums. You suspect lead poisoning, which among the following is false about it?

choices.text: It is a notifiable and compensatable disease
Lead sulphide is the most toxic lead compound
Inhalation is the mode of absorption in most cases
d-penicillamine as chelating agent is effective

questions.solution:
All the options statements regarding lead poisoning are true except B, as lead sulphide is considered the least toxic among other lead compounds.

Lead poisoning/Plumbism is a notifiable and compensatable disease.

Lead is a metallic inorganic irritant poison.Poisoning is more common from chronic occupational exposure from industries that utilize lead.

Industries that utilize lead are glass manufacture, shipbuilding, printing and potteries, storage batteries, and rubber industries.

All lead compounds are toxic - lead arsenate, lead oxide, and lead carbonate are the most dangerous; lead sulphide is the least toxic.

Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the mode od absorption seen in most cases. Other modes are ingestion and absorption through the skin.

Plumbism/saturnism/chronic lead poisoning presents with

Mnemonic-ABCDEF

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)

Management: d-penicillamine is reported to be an effective chelating agent.

questions.text: You are planning to conduct a randomized control trial to study the effect of an emollient for eczema, you consider two groups of which one group will receive a placebo. You are considering a blinding trial for this to prevent bias. Which among the following is the most frequent blinding that is used to conduct such trials?
questions.solution:
Although ideally triple blinding should be used, double-blinding is the most frequently used method when blinded-trials are conducted.

Double blinding trials is where neither the group members nor the observers are aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is called transovarial transmission. It is seen in Rickettsia rickettsii (in ticks).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child was vaccinated for measles. What is the correct schedule to be followed for the immunization regarding measles for this child now?

choices.text: The child should be given a second dose as soon as she reaches 9 months of age
The child should be given a second dose after 2 weeks of last dose
The child should be given a second dose after 6 weeks of last dose
The child should be given the second dose of measles at 12 months of age

questions.solution:
An infant immunized between 6-9 months should receive a second dose as soon as the child reaches 9 months of age.

While the scheduled age of receiving the measles vaccine is at 9 months, it can be lowered to 6 months during a measles epidemic in the community.

For infants immunized between 6 months to 9 months of age, a second dose should be administered as soon as the child reaches the age of 9 months, provided that 4 weeks have elapsed since the last dose.

questions.text: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is present bilaterally but not associated with any symptoms currently. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality?

choices.text: Persistent opening of first branchial cleft

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed from the first and second arches. 

The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.

 

Note: Collaural fistula is due to the persistent opening of the first branchial cleft.
